Dear Saima,

 

Thank you for summarizing the points. Please see my clarifications below.

 

Regarding the concern about compensation, I can confirm that the insurance company can and will compensate Zimmerman if they are added as an additional insured to the C&B policy. 

 

The cover is not invalidated as long as Zimmerman added as an insured entity and the relevant store assets are declared. This is a standard procedure and is the same structure we use for C&B and Al Heba, as well as H&C in Kuwait which covers Faces, Louboutin, and other brands under a single policy. Same also applies for UAE and KSA companies as well.

The cover is not invalidated as long as Zimmerman added as an insured entity and the relevant store assets are declared. This is a standard procedure and is the same structure we use for C&B and Al Heba, as well as H&C in Kuwait which covers Faces, Louboutin, and other brands under a single policy. Same also applies for UAE and KSA companies as well.

 

To answer your question on timing, setting up a new, separate insurance policy for Zimmerman directly is a lengthy process. It requires a full compliance and supplier creation cycle, which includes:

 

*	KYC – filled up signed by authorized signatory and stamped 
*	Memorandum of association copy
*	Shareholders’ identification document copies
*	Directors’ identification document copies, if not in shareholder list. Same for the authorized signatory.
*	Ultimate Beneficiary Chain to be established until all natural persons are established, and documentations of all entities provided.
*	Then we need to do internal supplier creation

 

This entire process is lengthy and time-consuming, especially for a single location. If it is possible to internally recharge the premium, that would be the most straightforward path forward.

 

Hope this clarifies the situation from an insurance perspective.

 

Best regards,

Hagop
